content.webTitle: How the Australian press saw the fourth day

fields.headline: 'A flame too easily extinguished'
fields.bodyText: "In just 127 minutes reports were dispelled that English cricket had sprung back to life and that the battle for the Ashes might be a contest after all. That's how long it took for England's batting line-up to crumble for 79." Sydney Morning Herald "England has been thumped. Hopes of an Ashes series capable of maintaining widespread attention crumbled as wickets fell on the fourth afternoon ... English resistance was a candle whose flame was too easily extinguished." The Age (Melbourne) "England had one excellent day, one fair one and two absolute stinkers, confirming everyone's suspicion that they have enough talent to muster a fighting hour, session or day, but nowhere near enough to sustain it day after day." The Courier-Mail (Brisbane) "Even by the lowly standards of England's recent humiliating Ashes history, yesterday's capitulation was remarkable. Drama, tragedy and farce were played out with continuing ineptitude as England lost by 384 runs, one of their worst failings in the 125 years of Anglo-Australian Test cricket ... The only defiance yesterday came from the wrong side of the fence as England's legion of rowdy supporters, the self-styled Barmy Army, continued to chant "Mighty, mighty England". The Australian
